attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description: Physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse balances indicated variances as follows; Bread -25.5 loaves, White flour +4.755 kg, Wheat Bran +4.995 kg, Yeast +1.093 and Utto +9.383 Litres. The rest stocks items had immaterial variances as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Utto variance should be investigated and correction done on BOM.
•    Stock controls on other items is recommendable and should be maintained.
attributes.effect:
•    Excess in utto is an indication that the current BOM is wrong and adjustments is required.
•    The rest of the stock had minimal variations and indication of good controls.

value: •    Stock controls in place are good and we shall maintain
•    We will investigate the positive variance.

In prior audit, most stock items had nil variations with exception to bread stock which had a variance of +30.50 loaves, poly bags -47.90 pieces (cumulative) and Gunny bags for 25kg and 50kg which had a variance of -43 pcs and 39 pcs respectively.

Stock take was conducted on 18th March 2025 to establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.
Utto variance should be investigated and adjustment done in BOM. The rest of the stocks items are well maintained.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that the company does not incur losses through stocks misappropriation.

attributes.title: Bread weight
attributes.description: From the samples picked, bread underweight were noted as follows; 600 BW – 32%, 400W  - 11%, 200ML - 14%, 400SN - 0%, 800W – 19% and 600W – 9% as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should tighten on adherence to the set out production standards so as to control production of under weight bread.
attributes.effect:
•     Presence of underweight bread is an indication that the company is exposed to the risk of penalties if caught by weight and measure officials.
•    Supplying underweight bread also damages company reputation.

value: •    We shall intensify our supervision to ensure to control underweight cases.
•    We shall continue to do random weight check to make sure our workers adhere to the set production standards.
In prior audit, underweights were observed across all the varieties sampled as follows;

•    Bread weight was taken from a sample selected from packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to determine whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.
Underweight bread was found across all varieties sampled except 400g brown bread, hence there exist weight compliance gaps.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure compliance with the minimum weight set standards

attributes.title: Bread Damages
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.24% of the total production and market damages stood at 0.37% of the total sales. 
•    Physical damages weighed compared to Manager’s records had a variance of +61.9kg equivalent to 154.75 loaves.


 Production damages analysis

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Market damages analysis
attributes.recommendation:
•    More effort should be put in place to control cases of production damages in the branch.
•    Proper records of damages should be kept to ensure physical damages match the manager’s record.
•    Damages should be kept in a secure place which should be under key and lock
attributes.effect: •    Production damages recorded for the period exceeded the set threshold exposing the company to a revenue loss of Kes 16,377.

value:
•    With the proposed safe storage of damages, we will ensure that there is accountability of physical damages in our custody.
•    We shall ensures production standards are adhered to at every production stage to minimize
•    We have made a request through DHO to have a secure space for damages to ensure there is accountability
•    In the previous audit, it was noted that the overall production damages were 0.25% of bread produced while market damages were 0.30% of sales.

•    Analysis of production and market damages was done for a period of 31 days - 15th Feb 2025 to 17th Mar 2025 to determine whether bread damages were within the desired percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales.
•    Production damages recorded for the period exceeded the set threshold by 0.04% while market damages were within the acceptable rate.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure the company does not lose revenue through excessive production and market damages.

attributes.title: Mixing Charts Analysis
attributes.description: •    It was noted that, Average production was 131.16 bags per day, which is 67% of the daily target of 195 bags. Yield achieved during the period was 190.33. Data transferred from the physical mixing charts to the cash flow and SAP was accurate.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch need to put more effort to achieve the set production target of 195 bags per day.
•    Cases of remix should be discouraged as it affects the bread quality.
attributes.effect: •    Underutilization implies that the branch does not take advantage of economies of scale.

value: •    Target shortfall is a result of production cuts as we plan our production as per orders. Our production capacity exceeds demand.
•    Production is based on the demand within and even for other branches in the region. We do bread transfers to other branches whose production capacity is limited.

•    In the previous audit, it was noted Average production was 109.90 bags per day representing 56.36% of target which is195 bags per day (Branch Capacity), Average yield was 190.16, Utto consumption was 100%.

•    An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 31 days from 15th Feb 2025 to 17th Mar 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM and if the set production standards were achieved.
The branch production capacity utilization was at 67% of the full capacity available leaving an idle capacity of 23%.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure production data provided reflect the actual production happening in a branch.

attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description:
•    Cash counted compared to cash flow balance had a minimal variance of Kshs. +2
•    There were two pending IOU’s – Kshs 2,000 advanced to Said Rama - Lodwar route for parking charges and Kshs 1,200 advanced to Meshack Khisa (employee) for medication. Both IOU’s were issued on 18th March 2025.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch cashier should maintain the cash controls in place

value: •    This is well noted
•    Well noted, we shall maintain.
•    Verification of cash held at the cash office was done on 19th March 2025, to confirm cash held by the cashier and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.
Cash controls in place are adequate
To confirm cash held by the cashier compared with the expected and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that, the total outstanding debtors amounted to Kes 2,799,928. It was further noted that one active institution (Kapenguria Boys high school) had Kes. 1,588,125 which is 57% of the total outstanding balances. 

Debtors analysis illustration;
attributes.recommendation:
•    Sales crew and the sales representative to ensure that bread supplied is paid for on delivery for customers without credit arrangement.
•    Follow up on institutions with credit arrangements to ensure payments are done on time
attributes.effect: •    Outstanding route balances for customers without credit arrangement can lead to bad debts and hence financial losses.

value: •    Sales representative to follow up on the accounts with balances.
•    An analysis of the route balances was done as at 17th March 2025 to ascertain the status thereof.
Most of the outstanding balances are for institutions with credit arrangements.
To ensure that route balances are well managed to avoid cases of bad debts.

attributes.title: Production efficiency
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.47 bags per production worker. 

A summary of production analysis is shown below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The production workers hired should be managed well to ensure they achieve the set target of 4.5 bags per production worker.
attributes.effect: •    Failure to achieve production target efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker implies the company incurred unbudgeted labour cost amounting to Kes 7,324.19

value: •    We always push our workers to achieve the set efficiency but there are few cases of breakdown during the period which affect the overall efficiency.
•    The production efficiency is too bad, slightly affected by shift cuts due to low demand.
•    In the prior audit, it was noted that the production efficiency was 4.35 bags per production worker.

•    Production efficiency was calculated for period of 31 days from 15th Feb 2025 to 17th Mar 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
Production efficiency achieved was 99% of the expected.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure there is optimal utilization of the production labour employed.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    Analysis revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 91.23 crates per slicer. 

The table below illustrates the findings;-
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure slicers are hired based on the workload and also they should be pushed to achieve the set efficiency.
attributes.effect: •    Failure to achieve the set packing efficiency, implies that the company incurred Kes 31,008 unbudgeted labour costs.

value: •    We will continue to push packers to reduce the inefficiency, there is a slight improvement compared to the previous audit finding.
•    There is a little improvement and I have advised the branch manager to make sure workers are hired based on the workload.
•    In the prior audit, it was found that the packing efficiency was 85.75 crates per slicer
•    Slicing Efficiency was computed for a period of 31 days from 15th February 2025 to 17th March 2025 to determine whether the set company standard of 97 crates per slicer was being achieved.
The branch failed to achieve the acceptable packing efficiency for the period reviewed.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure there is optimal utilization of the packing labour employed.

attributes.title: Vehicle fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that most branch vehicles had minimal variances from the set standards. 

Mileage Analysis Table
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch manager should continue to ensure sales vans fuel consumption is within the set standards.
attributes.effect: •    Fuel consumption within the set standards which implies adequate controls are in place to safe guard company resources.

value: •    We will continue to monitor sales vans fuel consumption
•    Fuel consumption is within the set standards.
•    In the prior audit, It was noted that all vehicles fuel consumption were within the set standards.
•    Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st March 2025 to 18th March 2025. To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
•    Fuel consumption is within the set standards which implies adequate controls are in place.
Transport/Fleet Department
To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for branch vehicles.
